== Criticism ==
== Criticism ==
â
Android has been criticized for not being all [[open-source software]] despite what was announced by Google. Parts of the [[SDK]] are [[proprietary software|proprietary]] and [[closed source software|closed source]] and some believe this is so that Google can control the platform.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://code.google.com/android/kb/licensingandoss.html#timeline |title=When will we see more code released under open source licenses? |publisher=[[Google]] |quote=''Over time, more of the code that makes up Android will be released, but at this point, we have been concentrating on shipping an SDK that helps application developers get started. In short: Stay tuned.'' |date=2008-01-29 |accessdate=2008-02-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.infoq.com/news/2007/11/dalvik |title=Dalvik, Android's virtual machine, generates significant debate |last=Slobojan |first=Ryan |publisher=infoq.com |date=2007-11-19 |accessdate=2008-03-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://ianskerrett.wordpress.com/2007/11/13/what-does-android-mean-for-suns-openjdk/ |title=What Does Android Mean for Sunâs OpenJDK |last=Topic |first=Dalibor |quote=''Android is proprietary, despite being marketed as open source. Android has a compatibility pledge, signed and kept behind closed doors. Android has no governance model, nor any indication there will be one. Android has no spec, and the license prohibits alternative implementations, as thatâs not a use licensed by Google in the SDK license. Android is completely controlled by Google, and Google reserves the right to kill off competitors applications if they hurt Google financially, etc. Itâs only as open as it is in Googleâs financial interest to allow openness, by design.'' |date=[[2007-11-14]] |accessdate=2008-02-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://robilad.livejournal.com/22312.html |title=QOTD: Google's license for the Android SDK |last=Topic |first=Dalibor |quote=There is a bunch of other rather objectionable stuff, but dear me, this is pretty bad as far as license agreements for pseudo-open-source software go |date=2007-11-12 |accessdate=2008-02-03}}</ref> The Android Software Development Kit License Agreement<ref>{{cite web |url=http://code.google.com/android/terms.html |title=Android Software Development Kit License Agreement |publisher=[[Google]] |date=2007-11-12 |accessdate=2008-02-03}}</ref> states that:
+
Android has been criticized for not being all [[open-source software]] despite what was announced by Google. Parts of the [[Software development kit|SDK]] are [[proprietary software|proprietary]] and [[closed source software|closed source]] and some believe this is so that Google can control the platform.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://code.google.com/android/kb/licensingandoss.html#timeline |title=When will we see more code released under open source licenses? |publisher=[[Google]] |quote=''Over time, more of the code that makes up Android will be released, but at this point, we have been concentrating on shipping an SDK that helps application developers get started. In short: Stay tuned.'' |date=2008-01-29 |accessdate=2008-02-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.infoq.com/news/2007/11/dalvik |title=Dalvik, Android's virtual machine, generates significant debate |last=Slobojan |first=Ryan |publisher=infoq.com |date=2007-11-19 |accessdate=2008-03-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://ianskerrett.wordpress.com/2007/11/13/what-does-android-mean-for-suns-openjdk/ |title=What Does Android Mean for Sunâs OpenJDK |last=Topic |first=Dalibor |quote=''Android is proprietary, despite being marketed as open source. Android has a compatibility pledge, signed and kept behind closed doors. Android has no governance model, nor any indication there will be one. Android has no spec, and the license prohibits alternative implementations, as thatâs not a use licensed by Google in the SDK license. Android is completely controlled by Google, and Google reserves the right to kill off competitors applications if they hurt Google financially, etc. Itâs only as open as it is in Googleâs financial interest to allow openness, by design.'' |date=[[2007-11-14]] |accessdate=2008-02-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://robilad.livejournal.com/22312.html |title=QOTD: Google's license for the Android SDK |last=Topic |first=Dalibor |quote=There is a bunch of other rather objectionable stuff, but dear me, this is pretty bad as far as license agreements for pseudo-open-source software go |date=2007-11-12 |accessdate=2008-02-03}}</ref> The Android Software Development Kit License Agreement<ref>{{cite web |url=http://code.google.com/android/terms.html |title=Android Software Development Kit License Agreement |publisher=[[Google]] |date=2007-11-12 |accessdate=2008-02-03}}</ref> states that:
{{quote|3.2 ''You agree that Google (or Google's licensors) own all legal right, title and interest in and to the SDK, including any intellectual property rights which subsist in the SDK. Use, reproduction and distribution of components of the SDK licensed under an open source software license are governed solely by the terms of that open source software license and not by this License Agreement. Until the SDK is released under an open source license, you may not extract the source code or create a derivative work of the SDK.''}}
{{quote|3.2 ''You agree that Google (or Google's licensors) own all legal right, title and interest in and to the SDK, including any intellectual property rights which subsist in the SDK. Use, reproduction and distribution of components of the SDK licensed under an open source software license are governed solely by the terms of that open source software license and not by this License Agreement. Until the SDK is released under an open source license, you may not extract the source code or create a derivative work of the SDK.''}}
